trans-unit.source: To create a VNet by using PowerShell, follow the steps below.
trans-unit.target: To create a VNet by using PowerShell, follow the steps below.

trans-unit.source: If you have never used Azure PowerShell, see <linkText>How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> and follow the instructions all the way to the end to sign into Azure and select your subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you have never used Azure PowerShell, see <linkText>How to Install and Configure Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title> and follow the instructions all the way to the end to sign into Azure and select your subscription.

trans-unit.source: From an Azure PowerShell prompt, run the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet to switch to Resource Manager mode, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: From an Azure PowerShell prompt, run the Switch-AzureMode cmdlet to switch to Resource Manager mode, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: The Switch-AzureMode cmdlet will be deprecated soon.
trans-unit.target: The Switch-AzureMode cmdlet will be deprecated soon.

trans-unit.source: When that happens, all Resource Manager cmdlets will be renamed.
trans-unit.target: When that happens, all Resource Manager cmdlets will be renamed.

trans-unit.source: If necessary, run the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet to create a new resource group, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: If necessary, run the New-AzureResourceGroup cmdlet to create a new resource group, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: For our scenario, create a resource group named TestRG.
trans-unit.target: For our scenario, create a resource group named TestRG.

trans-unit.source: For more information about resource groups, visit <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Overview</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about resource groups, visit <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Overview</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Run the New-AzureVirtualNetwork cmdlet to create a new VNet, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the New-AzureVirtualNetwork cmdlet to create a new VNet, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Run the Get-AzureVirtualNetwork cmdlet to store the virtual network object in a variable, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the Get-AzureVirtualNetwork cmdlet to store the virtual network object in a variable, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: You can combine steps 4 and 5 by running $vnet = New-AzureVirtualNetwork -ResourceGroupName TestRG -Name TestVNet -AddressPrefix 192.168.0.0/16 -Location centralus.
trans-unit.target: You can combine steps 4 and 5 by running $vnet = New-AzureVirtualNetwork -ResourceGroupName TestRG -Name TestVNet -AddressPrefix 192.168.0.0/16 -Location centralus.

trans-unit.source: Run the Add-AzureVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig cmdlet to add a subnet to the new VNet, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: Run the Add-AzureVirtualNetworkSubnetConfig cmdlet to add a subnet to the new VNet, as shown below.

trans-unit.source: Repeat step 6 above for each subnet you want to create.
trans-unit.target: Repeat step 6 above for each subnet you want to create.

trans-unit.source: The command below creates the BackEnd subnet for our scenario.
trans-unit.target: The command below creates the BackEnd subnet for our scenario.

trans-unit.source: Although you create subnets, they currently only exist in the local variable used to retrieve the VNet you create in step 4 above.
trans-unit.target: Although you create subnets, they currently only exist in the local variable used to retrieve the VNet you create in step 4 above.

trans-unit.source: To save the changes to Azure, run the Set-AzureVirtualNetwork cmdlet, as shown below.
trans-unit.target: To save the changes to Azure, run the Set-AzureVirtualNetwork cmdlet, as shown below.
